title: 105_s1907
content: REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR WETLAND RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EXPENSES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on wetland restoration and conservation expenses. The wetland restoration credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit against their tax for the sum of wetland restoration, conservation, and easement credits. The wetland restoration credit is based on expenditures paid or incurred by the taxpayer for that taxable year. The wetland restoration credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for wetland restoration expenditures paid or incurred during the taxable year. Wetland restoration expenditure refers to the restoration of farmed or converted wetlands to fully functioning wetland condition, following an approved restoration plan by the Natural Resources Conservation Service. The wetland restoration credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for restoration expenditures on farmed or converted wetlands, following an approved plan by the Natural Resources Conservation Service. Expenditures must be incurred within the first 5 years of the conservation agreement or easement and cannot include costs mandated by federal or state law. The wetland conservation credit allows taxpayers to claim a credit for restoration expenditures on farmed or converted wetlands. The credit is based on the applicable percentage of the Conservation Reserve Program rental rate and any certification fees paid for compliance. The wetland conservation credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for restoration expenditures on qualified wetlands under the Food Security Act of 1985. This includes certification fees paid for compliance with a qualified conservation agreement. The applicable percentage is determined based on the term of the conservation agreement. The applicable percentage for the wetland conservation credit is based on the term of the conservation agreement: 50% for 10-19 years, 60% for 20-29 years, and 70% for 30 years. If the taxpayer elects the wetland easement credit, the conservation credit is denied. The wetland conservation credit percentage is based on the conservation agreement term: 50% for 10-19 years, 60% for 20-29 years, and 70% for 30 years. If the taxpayer chooses the wetland easement credit, the conservation credit is forfeited. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, determined by a certified appraisal. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which it is made. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement, determined by a certified appraisal. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which it is made. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to a taxpayer who owns wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands, along with surrounding actively farmed cropland. The wetland easement credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the fair market value of qualified wetlands under a conservation easement. A qualified wetland includes wetlands, farmed wetlands, or prior converted wetlands, along with surrounding actively farmed cropland, under a qualified conservation agreement or easement. The term 'qualified wetland' refers to wetlands being converted to fully functioning wetland condition through restoration expenditures, along with surrounding nonwetland areas under a conservation agreement or easement. The term 'qualified wetland' includes surrounding nonwetland areas under a conservation agreement or easement, with certain exclusions. The term 'qualified wetland' includes surrounding nonwetland areas under a conservation agreement or easement, with certain exclusions such as land receiving payments from conservation programs. Wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland are defined as per the Food Security Act of 1985. The Food Security Act of 1985 defines wetland, farmed wetland, and prior converted wetland. A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement with a governmental unit for a term of at least 10 years. A qualified conservation agreement is an agreement with a governmental unit for a term of not less than 10 years and not more than 30 years, where the taxpayer agrees to comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland and obtain a certification of compliance. The taxpayer agrees to comply with conservation requirements for a qualified wetland and obtain a certification of compliance every 5 years. Compliance includes not using the wetland for agricultural production. The taxpayer complies with conservation requirements by not using the qualified wetland for agricultural production and refraining from manipulating it in any way that impairs water flow. The term 'qualified conservation easement' refers to an easement granted in perpetuity by the eligible taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for agricultural production or development of built structures. The term 'qualified conservation easement' means an easement granted in perpetuity by the eligible taxpayer to restrict the use of a qualified wetland for conservation purposes. No credit is allowed for expenses already deducted or credited under other provisions of the tax code. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for deduction or credit under other tax provisions. Additionally, married couples must file joint returns for this section to apply. Married couples must file joint returns for this section to apply. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998, regarding wetland restoration and conservation expenses and overpayments of tax.
